missing.text: The fundamental theorem states that if f is continuous on [a, b], then the integral from a to b of f'(x) dx equals f(b) - f(a)
This is a profound result that connects differentiation and integration in a beautiful way
Example: Find the integral from 0 to 2 of 3x² dx. First, we find the antiderivative: F(x) = x³. Then we evaluate F(2) - F(0) = 8 - 0 = 8
Second part of the fundamental theorem: If F(x) = integral from a to x of f(t) dt, then F'(x) = f(x)
Physics Applications: Work = ∫ F(x) dx = ΔPE (change in potential energy)
